item.title: Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us? — 79 replies — 316.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Is it really that much more difficult to start a business in the eu than us?

Open thread • Replies: 79 • Updated: 2026-02-19 22:42 UTC

OP

You guys in the EU make less than us on paychecks, but you get to keep more of your money because you have universal healthcare and PTO while we have to pay for private insurance which chronically denies people's health situations.

Are people saying that starting a business in the EU is difficult because of the regulations? What regulations does the European union impose on its citizen's than they think it's easier to start in the United States instead?

Early replies (first 3)

61860815
>>61860796
Depends enormously on which country are we talking about. Some are easy (Germany) some are very hard (Italy)

61860817
>>61860796
> you get to keep more of your money because you have universal healthcare
yeah right
good luck getting that "universal healthcare" if you're not a boomer, waiting lists are years for even a basic exam/procedure. It's either you go private (and pay out of your own pocket) or you die
> and PTO
oh wow, 20 wagie cagie free days a year. Totally worth the 60%+ taxes.

All taxation is theft. It's just that. Taxation doesn't pay for services. It's just the way they control the economy, and here in EU they fucking LOVE to control what you can and cannot do. They print the money, they don't need to tax you. They tax you to control you (and to humiliate you)

61860822
>>61860796
The healthcare thing is too much american leftie argument, it also has been very overcrowded by you guessed arabs and africans, unironically I was better treated when I broke my leg in brazil of all places then in france

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61870682
>>61870203
ah, i see, you are retarded. just because some laws that are lax exist doesn't mean data is protected, you fucking retarded faggot

61870744
>>61870065
it started long before post-WW2 tho, germs bureaucracymaxxed post-reunification during the 2nd Reich, from 1871 onward.
At first it was to keep in check all the landers trying to take the lion's share of federal credits and centralize power. And it worked gud, but then it progressively became the hellscape kafkaian machine we all know.
That's how you know the hallofcost never happened, becuz you can be sure nazis would have made endless paperworks addressing the situation, down to the very last jewish pubic hair, but we didn't find any document.

61870778
Stop eating the commie propaganda. Europeans don't have savings for shit, they just have stable expenses but all their wealth is tied to inheriting homes. That's why homes are basically untaxed while stocks are treated like financial Nazism. You aren't going to spend more a healthy young person in the US, the real benefit of Europe is the private healthcare is very cheap and good

Starting businesses in Europe sucks because of two factors. The first is low liquidity and consumer spending: unlike the US, people don't spend nearly as much, have as much to spend, or make debt. So there isn't much room for anyone to buy something new - successful businesses target liquid tourists or B2B, where they write off the huge taxes as expenses. Over regulated financial market also leads to lower liquidity and more difficulty getting loans and investors, you rely on government programs run by middle aged menopausal cunts that have never worked more than 28 hours a week

Other issue is labor laws and public perception. It's morally bankrupt to try and get more money, why aren't you happy being average, why are you trying to pull ahead. Anyone you hire can't be fired, you can't have low compensation with offset packages to get high skill labor, you need to suck some blue blooded cock to get money and not wait years for whatever permits you'll need, because they were born out of nobility and still have half the money and connections

Eurotards freak out about Epstein but every European politician and rich person rapes babies for breakfast. It's just 1) not pedo to them if they're over 14 bc muh age of consent and 2) they hide in the shadows unlike Americans, they try to be as unnoticed as possible, give a few concessions to the poor and continue ruling sucking and fucking like they've been doing the past thousand years

61870889
>>61870103
What are the reforms that boomers are blocking?

61870915
>>61869942
Yeah i feel the same. Sex, drugs and love are already the ultimate sensations and none of them are expensive. All luxuries are pretty worthless add-ons and don’t feel special. You just have a bigger bed, or a bigger car, not anything you really need.

61870937
>>61860817
That's complete bullshit, stop making up fantasies in your mind. If there is ONE thing still somewhat running smoothly in western Europe, it's free healthcare.
Contrary to you i know what i'm talking about since i was on the operation table just a month ago to fix few lower vertebrae after a bike accident. I never had to wait for anything more than few days, nor did i have to spend a single penny on pre-procedures, examinations or for the hospital stay/operation/anesthesia/post-op medication. And i don't have any health mutual.

It probably would have costed me a bazillion goybux in the jewSA.

61871000
>>61870937
Why the fuck would it cost bajillions, even shit insurance has a max out of pocket of like 10k. If you don't have a job medicaid literally covers everything for free, the real problem is half the people that qualify are too fucking stupid to sign up for it

Also if the accident wasn't your fault you could sue for big money, in Europe they're just like meh accidents happen enjoy the lifelong complications faggot. I will agree southern European health systems are pretty decent and their private healthcare is fantastic and cheap, but if you're German or some shit I'd rather have the US system, you guys pay more in healthcare tax than any American if you have a half decent job and if you get anything where you may actually die they just say, yeah you're fucked settle your affairs or the bureaucracy will give the rest of your family a stroke, no point trying any more it's an inefficient allocation of resources

61871020
>>61868041
This is extremely short-sighted of them, they will end up losing the capacity to compete and fall behind slowly, they actually already are, then when they slowly go on closing business left and right from ever increasing ineficiency. What else can they even do but borrow more and more for the worst possible spending a state can do, paying bills, a budget blackhole, increasing inflation and making money useless and as those countries get poorer the services will also get far far far worse and extremely corrupt, not even talking about how such aging will make it even worse. Honestly this is reading like what happened to argentina, greece and other latam and thirdies socialist govts did, it will work fine as long as the economy can keep it, when it starts to shrink it will be poverty hell. I will agree that america treats us workers pretty bad, but this welfare paradise of the EU won't work for long either, they will end up forced to cut things and get closer to us if they want to survive a world with China, India, US and former colonies being no longer mudhutts but mildly developed enough to make raw resources more expensive.

61871023
>>61860796
Lots of retards ITT.

Setting up a business is child's play in places like Denmark, Sweden, Estonia. Setting up, doing tax returns and all interactions with gov is handled through online ID and takes seconds.

Places like Bulgaria, Romania, Slovenia are selling themselves as business friendly. Very low taxes. Some places like Bulgaria have extremely low dividend taxes so you pay yourself with dividends. Romania has a corporate setup where you pay a tiny percentage on the turnover. Ideal for freelancers or small business with high margins or just extreme low expense. In all of these places, corporate setups and accountants cost next to nothing.

Then you have some almost offshore jurisdictions still in the EU with insanely beneficial rules for some niches and very low taxes. Like Cyprus and Malta.

Now regulations, what regulations? Anything (except guns, booze, some gambling, cigarettes I guess) is traded freely between the states under the same legislation.

Also: we get sued way less over here. Do the math on that one.

61871050
> wife started selling her paintings
> she declared herself first, this was needed to attend some events
> French government instantly asks her for €800, before she has made her first sale
> this is what they estimate she'd owe them at the end of the year based on their estimates of how much she will earn, so they ask for it upfront
> you can contest it but it's actually faster to wait for the year to end so they are proven wrong
I hate them so much...

61871051
>>61860860
>taxes
depends where, some places will legit rape your revenue
Combined with some insane regulations and you legit can't start a company
Best example is France, fucked up taxes, and if you want to get into tech, or anything that involves personal data, you need cough up 6 to 7 figures so that your cyber security is in the norm

61871089
>>61860815
This

61871111
>>61871020
I will die long before I see some high tech company or even mid tier industry appear in latam, africa or even india, they will always be turning up cheap raw resources because they are simply brown subhumans with low iq, not even talking about russia post-war. Its an unfounded fearmongering that we will ever have to compete with them lol, you forget europe will never fall to thirdie level of mismanagement simple because we are better educated and white. At the very worst unlikely scenario we will always make money from tourism anyway, but honestly this is all american envy for no reason, we are not stopping you from doing the same.

61871116
>>61871023
So you're admitting you can only live off arbitrage? Who the fuck are you selling to in Romania or Bulgaria, Romania is actually marginally based because it's spread its asshole to US companies for cheap EU labor, those Nordic countries you listed have a smaller economy than Pennsylvania so yeah if you want to sell troon support stickers you're good but you're not going to make shit otherwise

Portugal is also kind of based but it fully relies on US and other European investments, as well as inexistent enforcement of labor laws and pathetic salaries. I don't get how you'd start up there without the first 100k being gifted though, or the family having land, or working abroad first

As I said, Europe is only viable for tourism or B2B, you will never become a millionaire opening a bakery or car wash or hamster fentanyl university of arts like the US, there's no consumer spending to eat

61871180
>>61871116
>Europe is only viable for tourism or B2B, you will never become a millionaire
Lmao, just look at economic charts, most european economies have high tech industry as the main economic activity, american bullshit as usual, nobody needs to be a millionaire in europe, we already live better than one.

61871183
>>61871116
>Who the fuck are you selling to in Romania or Bulgaria,
As I said, you are a fucking retard. Your company is in Bulgaria, but you sell to fucking anyone in EU the same way while paying insanely low corporate tax and next to no admin fees. You ship from anywhere you want in the EU, or have staff in bloody Manila if you wish. What the fuck does that have to do with arbitrage? You incorporate wherever you want since it is your legal right.

I doubt you are entrepreneurial material though, so do not bother grokking the potential here.

61871191
>>61871000
The suing thing is the biggest AIDS of USA. People are already well compensated enough in europe for their troubles. The ”if you make a honest mistake, someone will see their opportinity and sue you and financially destroy your life” mentality just creates even more stress to an already high stress environment of USA. It just makes people act even more legally defensive at every turn and creates useless bureucracy and slows things down. Getting raped when everything didn’t go 100% nicely is not something to be proud of.

61871214
>>61871020
This is the most midwit take and the reason why USA is failing now (it has become a nation of midwits due to poor public education). People have been saying this for decades but right now europe is in a bullrun while USA has been becoming an oligarchic brasil since the 80s. Clearly socialism doesn't just lead to inefficiency but instead to more efficiency for all instead of just few hoarding the wealth.

61871353
>>61871183
Learn to read Fritz, you are saying what I'm saying while sounding like a mong. You're setting up in poor countries to sell to richer countries' businesses while using the common market, it's geographic arbitrage you sausage guzzling troon, and you're selling to businesses. All that free education and you're still poorer than a fucking car salesman in Pensacola

61871500
>>61871214

Excluding Pooland all major eu economies have stopped growing or deacelerated fast, people were saying it for decades with reason, if it wasnt for a miraculous fall of the ussr and a flood of cheap raw resources and energy with negligible transport costs from russia it would've happened earlier as it did post-2008 when europe started to lag more and more behind the US and China.

item.title: Finding a job — 11 replies — 44.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Finding a job

Open thread • Replies: 11 • Updated: 2026-02-19 22:30 UTC

OP

I live near Tampa FL and I'm wondering what are some viable strategies for actually finding work instead of applying to 1000 ghost job listings and praying someone calls me back?

Early replies (first 3)

61875498
>>61875447
Head to your nearest mcdonalds and talk to the manager. You'll be working by end of day.

61875501
>>61875498
I have an engineering degree I'd rather starve and be destitute than work in a factory or retail.

61875515
>>61875498
I'm trying to find stuff other than fucking McDonald's bro

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61875627
>>61875447
Sorry bro FL is literally the worst state in the union for jobs

Our fagnigger governor touts how much money he saves skimming off the annual budget yet the taxes remain insanely high the jobs are shit, the wages are laughable, no fault, right to work state. Its shit but a jewlovers dream

61875634
>>61875447
firm handshake direct eye contact

61875790
>>61875634

61875821
>>61875447
Church. Social network. LinkedIn by making a post asking your hundreds of connections to point you to a job.

61875852
>>61875447
Go to drinking place.
Talk to people.

61875930
>>61875498
This is bullshit boomer advice. McDonalds is full and they only want affirmative action subhumans.

61875971
>>61875447
I've gotten every job I've had by gaming LinkedIn. Add max number of connections each week.
>search for recruiter
>filter by target company
If they add you back send them a message about how you're considering applying to a role at their company and ask them some bullshit questions about company culture or whatever other corporate buzz words are popular at the moment. Hold a conversation instead of being full autistic. Then when you find a role you like start asking questions about the role (even if you already know the answer) with the goal of getting them to put you in direct touch with the hiring manager.

I'm in engineering (real engineering not SWE) so I ask them about NCEES licensure, inter-state reciprocity of license to practice engineering, or some technical questions for the role that HR would never be able to answer.

61876007
>>61875447
walk into a dealership. dont look like a weak faggot. profit.

item.title: Can we collectively decide to pump ROSE please? — 9 replies — 36.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Can we collectively decide to pump ROSE please?

Open thread • Replies: 9 • Updated: 2026-02-19 22:41 UTC

OP

Before you call me a retarded bag holder and that this is a dead coin (I am and am aware), I've seen you deranged retards come together for some miraculous feats for more impractical shit than this. For all the shit you can say about it, ROSE does have a use case. I think it was just too ahead of its time. Like myself, I'm assuming there's many others here who are still left holding a substantial amount, hoping and praying that it will one day go back up. Why couldn't we just as a group decide to pump this up and make it the next GME or AMD so that we can all cash out?

item.title: Vance — 5 replies — 9.8/hr
item.content:encoded:

61874936
>>61874905

61874965
>>61874899

61874974
>>61874965

61875001
>>61874974

61875052
>>61875001

>NO! NO! NO! Only WE'RE allowed to devalue our currency because WE need WAGESLAVES more than YOU! Y..you can't just print to build infrastructure!!! That's communist!!!!

61875074
>>61875052
I think the euros are more upset with china’s devaluation than America is. The guy in that article complaining is German.

They’re instantiating a levy on small goods in July to combat the yuan that refuses to budge.

61875077
>>61875001
How it's done? They just keep it tied to the dollar. What are you talking about?

61875121
>>61875077
It isn’t strictly tied to the dollar. It WAS before 2005, but now it’s a managed float system that is managed by the central bank. The dollar plays a big role, but it isn’t as if the yuan keeps strict pace with the dollar. They can (and do) manage its exchange rate. Exactly how they determine what the exchange rate should be is the opaque part. One way they manage the yuan’s value is by buying/selling dollars with their currency, and this is one reason why the keep so many dollars in reserve.

This is also why, earlier in the thread, I argued that the dollar’s role as a reference point for a currency can still cause it to be accumulated.

61875124
>>61872964
Sour fucking grapes. The Jews running the west are such idiots

61875149
>>61875074
Germans don't even believe in debt, they had a rule in their constitution that they couldn't borrow more than 0.35% of GDP annually until 2025 when shit hit the fan for needing to build a real military.
>Reee we aren't taking on debt so you can't either reeee

61875160
>>61873120
They’re disgusting gook bugmen that are not human

61875205
>>61874965
A currency cannot be "undervalued", because there is no "fair" or "inherent" value for a currency.

China keeps its currency stable relative to other currencies, mainly USD, to avoid currency exchange risk for exporting and importing companies.

China has a ridiculous surplus because (a) Chinese companies are ridiculously competitive, (b) Chinese companies are not allowed to import the kind of things they want to import because of export controls, (c) Chinese companies are afraid an over-dependence on imports will lead to them being rug-pulled by new export controls or piracy, and (d) the CPC has a "minimize China's dependence on others, maximize others' dependence on China" philosophy on how to win trade wars and avoid shooting wars.

61875302
>>61875205
Just because there isn’t an underlying physical commodity to back the currency doesn’t mean that the currency can’t still be undervalued (or overvalued). Parity for currencies, even currencies in a fiat system, is one way that this is calculated.

If a basket of various goods in the US goes for 100 dollars and that same basket of goods in Vietnam goes for 10 dollars (ALL ELSE BEING EQUAL), then a fair exchange rate would be 10 dong for one dollar. This is one way that these are calculated—people look at prices for similar goods, adjust for import and other costs, and determine how much that currency can actually purchase. When a country sets their own exchange rate, even if partially like in china’s case, it’s possible to undervalue it. They have an incentive to claim that their currency is weaker than it actually is.

So, no, that simply isn’t true. I know what you’re trying to say—fiat money has no intrinsic value—but it doesn’t mean that it can’t be undervalued or overvalued relative to other currencies. There’s a reason why economists or even someone casually interested in the economy and trade policy use these terms.

61875322
>>61875149
Reparations absolutely traumatized Germans in terms of their willingness to take on debt lol. They’ll have to do some serious heavy lifting in the EU soon, so I imagine they’ll start taking some more on.

61875497
>>61875322
It's already happened, they got rid of the limit and are doomping into their infrastructure and military

61875505
>>61873712
kek

61875517
>>61874965
>How do you think they have such a ridiculous surplus?
by being better than others at everything that matters

61875527
LMAO. Expecting Chinese to stop subsidising their industry is akin to asking Americans to stop eating Burgers.

61875528
>>61875497
Huh no kidding, I hadn’t been paying much attention to that. One thing I will be keeping an eye on is the EU pension crisis and how that’s managed because I personally don’t see a smooth exit from that situation, especially in France. Looking into it, I guess Germany has a similar problem, which I wouldn’t have guessed based on their debt. What’s your take?

61875554
>>61875121
It's between 6 and 8 Yuan so it's still tied to the dollar

61875563
>>61875517
Well, my point was that by managing the currency in order to keep it low, it makes exports more attractive, which results in a huge surplus. If the yuan floated freely, this would eventually correct. A huge trade surplus would mean more demand for the yuan and it would strengthen the currency. However, China doesn’t let this happen. If the currency strengthens or threatens to strengthen beyond what they deem desirable, they weaken their currency by selling yuan or by setting a lower daily exchange rate. This is the advantage of a managed currency, but it also means that it pisses everyone off when their own exports aren’t as competitive or their domestic industries suffer. China claims that they don’t this to the extent that they’re accused of, and it definitely comes in waves of egregiousness, but it seems like they’re back at it.

So yeah, it’s true they’re good at exporting, but their insane trade surplus is in part the result of what I’m describing (an undervalued yuan that is kept undervalued by china’s central bank).

61875564
>>61873590
>call western "social democracies" capitalist
We are 10 times more communist than china... with an extra helping of suicidal democracy

61875572
>>61875527
China doesn't subsidize their industries though
They just do things better and have more affordable standards of living

61875583
>>61873819
Wtf I love China now!

61875617
>>61875554
It can be undervalued and tied to the dollar. Read my post. You seem to think that because a currency’s exchange rate hasn’t changed that it can’t be undervalued or overvalued. That’s not true. Its real value in terms of purchasing power could rise and the central bank could artificially exert downward pressure (which would mean that the exchange rate would stay roughly the same over time). This is exactly what China has been accused of forever, and the issue is that China issue exactly forthcoming with their economic data.

It is obviously tied to the dollar. It is not STRICTLY PEGGED to the dollar. Every day the PBOC sets the exchange rate. The argument is that this rate hasn’t changed and has remained too low for how much demand there is for the yuan.

61875625
>>61875528
Well they're definitely going to bail the pension system out, but it should be kind of mitigated by the military and infrastructure spending because of their domestic industry. Adding money to those sectors should hypothetically cause more younger people to make more money, increasing direct contributions to the pension system. The bet that they're taking is that the spending won't increase inflation as much as it will improve the economic situation, which has some merit because Germany and even the rest of the EU have considerably lower debt to GDP than China or the US, and the currency has been appreciating broadly over the past few years giving them room for increased spending

61875629
>>61875572

Most of them are subsidised. They do not call them as subsidies but different names.

Source: Ran a Business sourcing products from multiple suppliers in China.

61875657
>>61873690

61875675
>>61875625
Interesting, good take. Definitely a situation to watch, particularly how the bailout happens. Getting a handle on youth unemployment, especially in France, should help, yeah. Realistically, I wonder if the pension system will be continued for much longer moving forward, and I think the French will lose their shit if it’s reformed in any meaningful way.

item.title: Would you have done the same? — 4 replies — 16.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
Would you have done the same?

Open thread • Replies: 4 • Updated: 2026-02-19 22:43 UTC

OP

I am a nurse at a large hospital's psych unit. I am also a newly graduated psychiatric nurse practitioner. I was about to start an NP job with a guaranteed salary of 150k with good benefits and a decent RVU bonus (bonuses for how many patients I see). However, this job has incredibly shady business practices, terrible reviews from former employees and was far away from home. The job was in a northern suburb of Dallas-Fort Worth, Texas. It was three 12 hour shifts in a row without a lunch break. I was supposed to start in early April.

I resigned last night in favor of a job close to family in a rural area in the southeast USA. This job pays me a 6,000$ a month draw and 67% of my collections. After I pay off the draw in a few months I could make as much money as I want, but that is contingent on the amount of patients I see. I can work as much or as little as I want. Take as much lunch break as I want. Benefits are offered W-2, but the health insurance is expensive. Here I will be doing real psychiatry and not corporate slop crap psychiatry. Also, my family is very happy about me staying close to home.

Basically I am trading certain money at a shit job for uncertain money (albeit a higher ceiling) at a good job. I talked to one of the NPs at the new place and he says that he makes about 24,000$ a month before taxes after working for 5 years. This would be almost double what I would have made in Frisco.

Do you think I made the right choice? Would you have done the same?

Early replies (first 3)

61875728
>>61875715
so you took a better job, for higher pay, to live in a lower cost of living area with more flexibility and closer to family?
wow, just wow anon. you fucked up big

61875759
No one knows because every fag online claims he makes 300k a year now. No one knows what a good job is anymore.

61875878
>>61875728
True, but there is a worst case scenario where I am getting almost no patients and stuck in the draw for much longer than anticipated. Although if I work 5-6 days a week I doubt this will happen. Also, If I somehow get fired while still paying the draw I have to pay it all off in 10 days, which would be nightmare scenario. There is more risk with the good job.
